bioghist.p: Kanji Dwarkadas (b. 1892) was a prominent Indian labor reformer. He was a member for Labour in the Bombay Legislative Council (1921-1923); member of the Industrial Dispute Committee and of the Prostitution Inquiry Committee (1922); one of the founding members of the All-India Trade Union Congress; treasurer and secretary of the All-India Home Rule League and member of the National Home Rule League (during the period when Annie Besant was that group's president); founding member of the Children's Aid Society (established 1927) and later secretary of that group (1938-1941). His published works include Forty-five Years with Labour, Ruttie Jinnah; the Story of a Great Friendship, and Ten Years to Freedom.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Kanji Dwarkadas, including correspondence and manuscripts of articles, letters to the editor, and reports of interviews. The correspondence relates to Dwarkadas's involvement in Indian politics, trade unions, and children's and women's welfare. Correspondents include: Annie Besant, Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyer, D. G. Pole, Shiva Rao, P. K. Telang, C. R. Attlee, Jinnah, Arthur Nethercot, and many others. Other materials in the collection include minutes from the Children's Aid Society, the Prostitution Committee, the Home Rule for India League; and reports by various individuals related to Indian politics and economic and social issues.
